thread.title: Kiwi man Brendon Demmocks injured in horror water accident in Australia
thread.title_full: Kiwi man Brendon Demmocks injured in horror water accident in Australia

author: Tommy Livingston
title: Kiwi man Brendon Demmocks injured in horror water accident in Australia
text:
Kiwi man Brendon Demmocks injured in horror water accident in Australia TOMMY LIVINGSTON Last updated 17:04, February 26 2017 
Brendon Demmocks, who is fighting for his life after a horror accident on The Murray River, with his nephew Riley, in a photo supplied by family. 
A New Zealander is fighting for his life in an Australian hospital after a horror water accident left him with a fractured skull. 
Brendon Demmocks was biscuiting with friends on the Murray River last weekend when he was propelled headfirst into a tree. 
His sister Samantha Venis said the accident had left her 31-year-old brother with life-threatening injuries. Rachel Orr 
Demmocks had been on a bisciut like the one pictured. 
Demmocks, along with two other men, were on the biscuit when it began to move towards a tree, the other two managed to get off, but Demmocks did not. READ MORE: * Vibrant Kiwi injured in crash 
"As they came around the corner the biscuit started to drift towards some of the trees. Because Brendon was on the middle he could not get off in time. He hit the tree head first on his left-hand side," Venis said. 
"They managed to get him on the boat pretty quickly. He coughed up some stuff and was swearing a little bit, and then he went unconscious." 
A series of infections, which have now spread to his lungs, had caused him serious setbacks. A team of over 20 doctors at a Melbourne hospital had been working to nurse him back to health. "He has multiple skull fractures and multiple brian bleeds," Venis said. 
"He has also got several fractures in his neck, and his T5 vertebrae. He is very heavily sedated." 
The outlook for Demmocks was unknown, his sister said. The possibility of paralysis, or worse, was very real. Ad Feedback 
"They have said it is not uncommon for people to be in comas for over two weeks," she said. 
"Because he was speaking after it happened, they said it was a really good sign. Everyday is one step forward, two steps back. It is very emotional." 
Demmocks had been living in Australia since last year working as a diesel mechanic. Originally from Amberley, Canterbury, he had planned on coming home next month to surprise his mum. 
"He had booked flights home for the 12th of March, because it is her birthday on the 13th. He had booked flights home to surprise her." 
Instead, his mother was keeping a vigil by his bedside. His siblings had also been with him, hoping he would pull through. 
"Leaving him yesterday was the hardest part. I just don't know what is going to happen. I have come home to see my husband and daughter for a few days. 
"I want us all to be there when he wakes up. It is a nightmare." 
A Givealittle page to help with the family's expenses can be found here . - Stuff
